General course objectives:
General course objectives
Apply thermodynamic property models to analyze and model downstream processing systems. Use systematic methods (graphical, short-cut, systems of equations) to model and analyze technically important multicomponent separation processes. Understand mechanisms for separation (solute transport in different semipermeable membrane types, phase distribution, surface interaction).
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Derive expressions for fugacity, enthalpy and entropy from an Equation of State
Use, and account for, the requirements and limitations the fundamental laws of thermodynamics impose on a given process
Choose thermodynamic models for liquid- and vapor mixtures with the aim of calculating phase equilibrium and state functions
Perform simple VLE and LLE calculations for multicomponent mixtures using activity coefficient models, as well as equations of state
Analyze separation processes, using graphical techniques
Analyze multicomponent separation processes, using modelling
Formulate and solve simple (non)equilibrium-based process simulation problems
Analyze sorption separation processes, using modelling
Derive equations for solvent and solute transport in pressure driven membrane processes.
Calculate how concentration and eventually temperature polarization influence the solute transport for the different membrane processes
Describe the function of the main used membrane modules and how they are used in different membrane processes.
Calculate mean flux, selectivity and membrane area for different membrane processes.
Content: Thermodynamics applied to separation process models: Fugacity, enthalpy and entropy from an Equation of State. Thermodynamic process limitations. Thermodynamic models for liquid- and vapor mixtures with the aim of calculating phase equilibrium and state functions. VLE and LLE calculations for multicomponent mixtures using activity coefficient models, as well as equations of state. Separation process analysis: Graphical techniques, mathematical modelling. Process simulation. Sorption separation processes, using modelling. Unit operations associated with membrane technology. Solvent and solute transport in pressure driven membrane processes. Concentration and temperature polarization. Common membrane modules and how they are used in different membrane processes. Mean flux, selectivity and membrane area for different membrane processes.
